qas.question: What type of layers do oak forests have plenty of?
What type of soils do most mesic forests have?
What type of rock do rhododendrons grow near?
What is rarely found near moist areas?
What is the name of the shrub associated with the chinquapin oak?

context: The oak forests generally lack the diverse <b0_0>small tree, shrub and herb<b0_0/> layers of mesic forests. Shrubs are generally ericaceous, and include the evergreen mountain laurel (<b4_0>Kalmia latifolia<b4_0/>), various species of blueberries (Vaccinium spp.), black huckleberry (Gaylussacia baccata), a number of deciduous rhododendrons (azaleas), and smaller heaths such as teaberry (Gaultheria procumbens) and trailing arbutus (Epigaea repens ). The evergreen <b3_0>great rhododendron<b3_0/> (Rhododendron maximum) is characteristic of moist stream valleys. These occurrences are in line with the prevailing <b1_0>acidic<b1_0/> character of most oak forest soils. In contrast, the much rarer chinquapin oak (Quercus muehlenbergii) demands alkaline soils and generally grows where <b2_0>limestone<b2_0/> rock is near the surface. Hence no ericaceous shrubs are associated with it.
